Kids of all ages may wonder and worry about COVID-19 too. Adults can help them make sense of it and manage their concerns:

-Remain calm
-Reassure them that they are safe
-Make yourself available to listen and talk
-Avoid language that blames others and may lead to stigma
-Pay attention to what they see and hear about it on TV, radio, and online
-Provide info that is truthful and appropriate
-Teach everyday actions to reduce the spread of germs

Learn more: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/talking-with-children.html

"Small rural school districts may not share the same geography, but they often share similar challenges and perhaps even student opportunities. But first, they listen.

District connections between DeRuyter Central School District and Otselic Valley Central School District arose in August when Mr. Dean Hathaway and Mr. Paul O’Connor, presidents of their respective Boards of Education, attended each other’s school board meetings.

There was no specific agenda for these meetings beyond getting acquainted, as both Hathaway and O’Connor made clear. “The DeRuyter board reached out to us to communicate and brainstorm about moving our two schools forward,” said Mr. O’Connor in the OV meeting..."

Read more on our website: https://www.ovcs.org/protected/ArticleView.aspx?iid=52BUGB&dasi=200

Otselic Valley Central School District added 77 new photos.
June 10 at 12:42 PM ·

While a traditional senior breakfast wasn't possible this year, a drive-through Senior Celebration still included fundamentals: food, cap and gown pickup, delivery of art portfolios and student journals, return of band instruments and folders, a senior slideshow including Carter Rood who remains a part of us, and the long, affectionate memory of Ms. Blake: "Congratulations Tootsy Wootsy Honey Bunnies!" New this year, of course, were special Class of 2020 face masks and t-shirts, and car decorating materials.

Many thanks to everyone who made this possible. There were a lot of you.

We also appreciate family members who picked up materials on behalf of their seniors who couldn't attend, and those who rode along with their graduates.

(No, we didn't forget the gold and black school colors. It was so hot and sunny that our black balloons absorbed more light, transferred that to heat, and popped in the sun before students even arrived. Ms. Blake wanted you to know.)

Otselic Valley always finds a way.

We were very sorry to learn of the passing of Mrs. Shirlee Langone, a reading teacher at Otselic Valley for about 10 years.

Before retiring from OV in 1998, she drove to school from Waterville every day. She is remembered for having a good heart and meaning well, and for helping any student who needed help with anything. Former staff may recall the lunch group who ate together in the Home Ec room daily. They were a memorable group of friends and colleagues.

As you might expect from a reading teacher, her obituary is rich with detail and communicates a great deal more.

Reading is at the heart of education, and we cannot overstate our thanks to all who help students "crack the code" of reading and learning, like Mrs. Langone.

Our warmest sympathies are extended to her family, friends, colleagues, and former students. RIP, Shirlee.

Ms. Ramsay and Ms. Shoemaker are part of the team that gets meal deliveries to students each weekday. Turns out, April Fools Day is especially fun!

Ms. Ramsay explained the photos: "Hiding in the window is Ian. He tried to play an April Fools joke on us to have the balloon pop out at us when we opened the cooler by the road. 🥰 The Marshall girls are out there every morning waiting at the door to say good morning and wave to us! We love to see their smiling faces. We miss them all!!"

There was more... I opened up the cooler and bam!" added Ms. Shoemaker. "It totally made my day."

Smiling faces are always the best part of every delivery day, we can see, and they never cost a thing. Today provided reason number 10 billion why we love Otselic Valley.

UPDATE: Sunday evening, March 22

Meal distribution will start again tomorrow, Monday, March 23rd. The buses will leave about 9:00 AM like last week.

**Please keep all pets contained to avoid spilled meals or their jumping on staff. If you have a cooler, box, or tote--just something the meals could be put in at the end of your driveway or porch--this will be so helpful. This lets us maintain social distancing as recommended by the state and federal government.**

Some students may get more materials tomorrow. We hope to send out a message either by School Messenger or Facebook or both when the buses leave school so you can watch for the bus and safely get those materials.

Again we appreciate what you are doing with your children as we progress with our new "normal." We know it isn't easy but everyone is doing a great job! We will get through this and be stronger for it.

Have a good evening.

We will also continue to deliver meals to the students at their homes. Please contact the school with any questions.

The Otselic Valley school building is now CLOSED except to essential staff on Thursday and Friday. Email, not phone, is now the best way to reach staff.

Our custodial team is working on a deep cleaning of our facilities, and we discourage in-person gathering during this COVID-19 outbreak.

We have tried to get educational materials, instruments, and personal things home to all students. If they are missing anything, email us with information and we will do our best to send them on the buses during food runs each day.

Thank you for your understanding during this unusual time.
